awd_titl_txt: NSF's National Optical-infrared Astronomy Research Laboratory (NOARL) Transition Planning and Preparation Project
awd_abstract_narration:
The NCOA Transition Planning and Preparation Project encompasses the planning and preparation necessary to complete the transition from operating the Gemini Observatory, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory (NOAO), and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) as independent observatories to operating them under a single, integrated National Center for Optical-Infrared Astronomy (NCOA) supported by centralized services and a matrix management structure for operations.  

NCOA will: (1) be the U.S. national Center for ground-based, nighttime optical and infrared (OIR) astronomy; (2) operate and maintain OIR observational research facilities and related data systems; (3) develop, build, coordinate, and integrate observational, technical, and data-oriented capabilities available throughout the U.S. OIR System of federal and nonfederal assets; (4) initiate, develop, and sustain domestic and international collaborations and partnerships to advance ground-based OIR facilities and capabilities; and (5) develop and advance a strategic vision for NSF-funded OIR capabilities in collaboration with community scientists, partner organizations, other U.S. OIR System operators, and NSF.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NOIRLab Transition Project Outcomes Report

Document Reference Code: NOIR-01-NDO-RPT-000242

Project Overview:

With support from this award, AURA prepared to execute a phased launch of NSF's National Optical-Infrared Astronomy Research Laboratory (NOIRLab, formerly NCOA).  NOIRLab integrates the operations of Gemini Observatory, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory, and the Vera C. Rubin Observatory (formerly the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope).  These NSF-supported national facilities previously operated as independent observatories.  With the launch of NOIRLab, they are operated within a single, integrated national laboratory (NOIRLab) supported by centralized services and a matrix management structure.

 

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

The preparatory activities supported by this award led to the successful establishment of NOIRLab.  NOIRLab is now the US national Center for ground-based, nighttime optical and infrared (OIR) astronomy.  As the national center, NOIRLab (i) operates and maintains OIR observational research facilities and related data systems; (ii) develops, builds, coordinates, and integrates observational, technical, and data-oriented capabilities available throughout the US OIR System of federal and nonfederal assets; (iii) initiates, develops, and sustains domestic and international collaborations and partnerships to advance ground-based OIR facilities and capabilities; and (iv) develops and advances a strategic vision for NSF-funded OIR capabilities in collaboration with community scientists, partner organizations, other US OIR System operators, and NSF.

 

Broader Impact Outcomes:

The launch of NOIRLab positions the US OIR observational community for scientific leadership in the era of the Vera C. Rubin Observatory and data-intensive astronomy into the 2020s and beyond.  NOIRLab will make NSF-sponsored US OIR astronomy more competitive on national and international levels via unified strategic planning and tactical implementation; this includes NOIRLab's possible role in the US-ELT Program.  NOIRLab is strengthening STEM workforce development by serving as a national focal point to recruit, develop, and retain a diverse and inclusive team of scientific and technical personnel. Moreover, the integration of federally-funded observatory operations will maximize scientific return on investment through the consolidation and standardization of administrative and management functions across the Lab.  NOIRLab's strengthened Communications, Education, and Engagement team will prepare the next generation of scientists and engineers, enhance education and public awareness of the astronomical sciences, and engage the general public in NOIRLab scientific and technical accomplishments that advance science for all humanity.
